channel.title: oracle on Roy Tang
channel.description: Recent content in oracle on Roy Tang

item.title: Reply to 'how to reference an oracle pl/sql out parameter of table%rowtype as an object in java' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8483352/how-to-reference-an-oracle-pl-sql-out-parameter-of-tablerowtype-as-an-object-in:
item.author: hello@roytang.net (Roy Tang)
item.description:
Reply to 'how to reference an oracle pl/sql out parameter of table%rowtype as an object in java' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8483352/how-to-reference-an-oracle-pl-sql-out-parameter-of-tablerowtype-as-an-object-in:

“rowtype” here is an Oracle PL/SQL-specific type, I don’t think it would be supported by JDBC. A quick search of the oracle forums (google “jdbc rowtype site:oracle.com”) suggests the same. You’re probably better off returning a cursor, or just execute the SQL from JDBC directly.

item.title: Reply to 'Oracle Insert with mutli-valued column' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3243055/oracle-insert-with-mutli-valued-column:
item.author: hello@roytang.net (Roy Tang)
item.description:
Reply to 'Oracle Insert with mutli-valued column' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3243055/oracle-insert-with-mutli-valued-column:

Try something like this:

insert into onTeam(date, player, teamName) 
select 'newDate','Matt Holliday', teamName 
from onTeam where player = 'Matt Holliday'

item.title: Reply to 'comparing two cursors in oracle instead of using MINUS' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2496360/comparing-two-cursors-in-oracle-instead-of-using-minus:
item.author: hello@roytang.net (Roy Tang)
item.description:
Reply to 'comparing two cursors in oracle instead of using MINUS' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2496360/comparing-two-cursors-in-oracle-instead-of-using-minus:

MINUS is the same as saying “get all the rows of the first query, then from that set remove the rows that are also in the second query”, so you could like load the results from the first query into an array in-memory, then loop through the second query results and check them one-by-one against the first query results and remove them if they exist.

I’m not sure that will actually perform better though (depends on a lot of things). You might also want to consider using NOT EXISTS instead and check that performance, i.e.

SELECT  RTRIM(LTRIM(A.HEAD)),
  A.EFFECTIVE_DATE,
FROM   TABLE_1 A
WHERE  A.TYPE_OF_ACTION='6'
AND    A.EFFECTIVE_DATE >= ADD_MONTHS(SYSDATE,-15)  
AND NOT EXISTS (
  SELECT 1 fFROM TABLE_2 B
  WHERE RTRIM(LTRIM(A.HEAD)) = RTRIM(LTRIM(B.HEAD))
  AND A.EFFECTIVE_DATE = B.EFFECTIVE_DATE
)

Some functional indexing may also be needed on RTRIM(LTRIM(A.HEAD))

item.title: New note
item.author: hello@roytang.net (Roy Tang)
item.description: I know the oci driver can perform transparent failover of the database, but does the thin driver have the same capability?

item.title: Reply to 'triggers statement level atomicity' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1859411/triggers-statement-level-atomicity:
item.author: hello@roytang.net (Roy Tang)
item.description:
Reply to 'triggers statement level atomicity' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1859411/triggers-statement-level-atomicity:

It means that any single SQL statement you run is atomic in nature - it will either succeed completely or fail completely. If your SQL statement fails, and triggers that would have run as a result of that SQL statement will fail as well.

item.title: Reply to 'Detect chinese (multibyte) character in a string in a column in oracle database' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1831114/detect-chinese-multibyte-character-in-a-string-in-a-column-in-oracle-database:
item.author: hello@roytang.net (Roy Tang)
item.description:
Reply to 'Detect chinese (multibyte) character in a string in a column in oracle database' on stackoverflow at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1831114/detect-chinese-multibyte-character-in-a-string-in-a-column-in-oracle-database:

Try “where length(column) < lengthb(column)”
